speaker: he
text: Whatever have you been doing with yourself, Watson?

speaker: he
text: You are as thin as a lath and as brown as a nut.

speaker: he
text: Poor devil!

speaker: he
text: What are you up to now?

speaker: Unknown
text: Looking for lodgings,

speaker: Unknown
text: Trying to solve the problem as to whether it is possible to get comfortable rooms at a reasonable price.

speaker: he
text: That's a strange thing,

speaker: he
text: you are the second man to-day that has used that expression to me.

speaker: Unknown
text: And who was the first?

speaker: he
text: A fellow who is working at the chemical laboratory up at the hospital. He was bemoaning himself this morning because he could not get someone to go halves with him in some nice rooms which he had found, and which were too much for his purse.

speaker: he
text: By Jove!

speaker: his
text: if he really wants someone to share the rooms and the expense, I am the very man for him. I should prefer having a partner to being alone.

speaker: his
text: You don't know Sherlock Holmes yet,

speaker: him
text: perhaps you would not care for him as a constant companion.

speaker: him
text: Why, what is there against him?

speaker: his
text: Oh, I didn't say there was anything against him. He is a little queer in his ideas--an enthusiast in some branches of science. As far as I know he is a decent fellow enough.

speaker: Unknown
text: A medical student, I suppose?

speaker: his
text: No--I have no idea what he intends to go in for. I believe he is well up in anatomy, and he is a first-class chemist; but, as far as I know, he has never taken out any systematic medical classes. His studies are very desultory and eccentric, but he has amassed a lot of out-of-the way knowledge which would astonish his professors.

speaker: his
text: Did you never ask him what he was going in for?

speaker: his
text: No; he is not a man that it is easy to draw out, though he can be communicative enough when the fancy seizes him.

speaker: his
text: I should like to meet him,

speaker: his
text: If I am to lodge with anyone, I should prefer a man of studious and quiet habits. I am not strong enough yet to stand much noise or excitement. I had enough of both in Afghanistan to last me for the remainder of my natural existence. How could I meet this friend of yours?

speaker: his
text: He is sure to be at the laboratory,

speaker: his
text: He either avoids the place for weeks, or else he works there from morning to night. If you like, we shall drive round together after luncheon.

speaker: his
text: Certainly,

speaker: Unknown
text: You mustn't blame me if you don't get on with him,

speaker: Unknown
text: I know nothing more of him than I have learned from meeting him occasionally in the laboratory. You proposed this arrangement, so you must not hold me responsible.

speaker: him
text: If we don't get on it will be easy to part company,

speaker: him
text: It seems to me, Stamford,

speaker: him
text: that you have some reason for washing your hands of the matter. Is this fellow's temper so formidable, or what is it? Don't be mealy-mouthed about it.

speaker: him
text: It is not easy to express the inexpressible,

speaker: him
text: Holmes is a little too scientific for my tastes--it approaches to cold-bloodedness. I could imagine his giving a friend a little pinch of the latest vegetable alkaloid, not out of malevolence, you understand, but simply out of a spirit of inquiry in order to have an accurate idea of the effects. To do him justice, I think that he would take it himself with the same readiness. He appears to have a passion for definite and exact knowledge.

speaker: him
text: Very right too.

speaker: him
text: Yes, but it may be pushed to excess. When it comes to beating the subjects in the dissecting-rooms with a stick, it is certainly taking rather a bizarre shape.

speaker: him
text: Beating the subjects!

speaker: Unknown
text: Yes, to verify how far bruises may be produced after death. I saw him at it with my own eyes.

speaker: him
text: And yet you say he is not a medical student?

speaker: Unknown
text: No. Heaven knows what the objects of his studies are. But here we are, and you must form your own impressions about him.

speaker: his
text: I've found it! I've found it,

speaker: his
text: I have found a re-agent which is precipitated by hoemoglobin, and by nothing else.

speaker: his
text: Dr. Watson, Mr. Sherlock Holmes,

speaker: his
text: How are you?

speaker: his
text: You have been in Afghanistan, I perceive.

speaker: his
text: How on earth did you know that?

speaker: his
text: Never mind,

speaker: Unknown
text: The question now is about hoemoglobin. No doubt you see the significance of this discovery of mine?

speaker: Unknown
text: It is interesting, chemically, no doubt,

speaker: Unknown
text: but practically--

speaker: Unknown
text: Why, man, it is the most practical medico-legal discovery for years. Don't you see that it gives us an infallible test for blood stains. Come over here now!

speaker: Unknown
text: Let us have some fresh blood,

speaker: his
text: Now, I add this small quantity of blood to a litre of water. You perceive that the resulting mixture has the appearance of pure water. The proportion of blood cannot be more than one in a million. I have no doubt, however, that we shall be able to obtain the characteristic reaction.

speaker: Unknown
text: Ha! ha!

speaker: his
text: What do you think of that?

speaker: his
text: It seems to be a very delicate test,

speaker: his
text: Beautiful! beautiful! The old Guiacum test was very clumsy and uncertain. So is the microscopic examination for blood corpuscles. The latter is valueless if the stains are a few hours old. Now, this appears to act as well whether the blood is old or new. Had this test been invented, there are hundreds of men now walking the earth who would long ago have paid the penalty of their crimes.

speaker: his
text: Indeed!

speaker: his
text: Criminal cases are continually hinging upon that one point. A man is suspected of a crime months perhaps after it has been committed. His linen or clothes are examined, and brownish stains discovered upon them. Are they blood stains, or mud stains, or rust stains, or fruit stains, or what are they? That is a question which has puzzled many an expert, and why? Because there was no reliable test. Now we have the Sherlock Holmes' test, and there will no longer be any difficulty.

speaker: his
text: You are to be congratulated,

speaker: his
text: There was the case of Von Bischoff at Frankfort last year. He would certainly have been hung had this test been in existence. Then there was Mason of Bradford, and the notorious Muller, and Lefevre of Montpellier, and Samson of new Orleans. I could name a score of cases in which it would have been decisive.

speaker: his
text: You seem to be a walking calendar of crime,

speaker: his
text: You might start a paper on those lines. Call it the 'Police News of the Past.'

speaker: Sherlock Holmes
text: Very interesting reading it might be made, too,

speaker: Lefevre
text: I have to be careful,

speaker: Unknown
text: for I dabble with poisons a good deal.

speaker: his
text: We came here on business,

speaker: Sherlock Holmes
text: My friend here wants to take diggings, and as you were complaining that you could get no one to go halves with you, I thought that I had better bring you together.

speaker: Lefevre
text: I have my eye on a suite in Baker Street,

speaker: Unknown
text: which would suit us down to the ground. You don't mind the smell of strong tobacco, I hope?

speaker: Unknown
text: I always smoke 'ship's' myself,

speaker: Unknown
text: That's good enough. I generally have chemicals about, and occasionally do experiments. Would that annoy you?

speaker: Unknown
text: By no means.

speaker: Unknown
text: Let me see--what are my other shortcomings. I get in the dumps at times, and don't open my mouth for days on end. You must not think I am sulky when I do that. Just let me alone, and I'll soon be right. What have you to confess now? It's just as well for two fellows to know the worst of one another before they begin to live together.

speaker: Unknown
text: I keep a bull pup,

speaker: Unknown
text: and I object to rows because my nerves are shaken, and I get up at all sorts of ungodly hours, and I am extremely lazy. I have another set of vices when I'm well, but those are the principal ones at present.

speaker: Unknown
text: Do you include violin-playing in your category of rows?

speaker: Unknown
text: It depends on the player,

speaker: Unknown
text: A well-played violin is a treat for the gods--a badly-played one--

speaker: Unknown
text: Oh, that's all right,

speaker: Unknown
text: I think we may consider the thing as settled--that is, if the rooms are agreeable to you.

speaker: Unknown
text: When shall we see them?

speaker: Unknown
text: Call for me here at noon to-morrow, and we'll go together and settle everything,

speaker: his
text: All right--noon exactly,

speaker: his
text: By the way,

speaker: his
text: how the deuce did he know that I had come from Afghanistan?

speaker: Unknown
text: That's just his little peculiarity,

speaker: him
text: A good many people have wanted to know how he finds things out.

speaker: him
text: Oh! a mystery is it?

speaker: him
text: This is very piquant. I am much obliged to you for bringing us together. 'The proper study of mankind is man,' you know.

speaker: Unknown
text: You must study him, then,

speaker: Unknown
text: You'll find him a knotty problem, though. I'll wager he learns more about you than you about him. Good-bye.

speaker: him
text: Good-bye,
